title: The Futurists - EPS_292: Foresight with Joanna Lepore and Ross Dawson

rawLines.text: this week on the futurist Joanna Laapore
Our brains and our hearts are trained to
be open to possibilities Like we're
curious by nature We are um entranced by
novelty Like we we design things just
because we can because we want to know
what it could possibly lead to I mean
like if you can tap into that from a
business perspective wow huge
opportunities
[Music]
I'm Ross Dawson guest hosting the
Futurist podcast this week Brett and Rob
are super super busy speaking and
working with clients around the world so
I'm stepping in I've been a professional
futurist for well over two decades now
and a close colleague of Brett and Rob
I've been a guest on the show before and
delighted to switch hats and be the host
This week I'm delighted to have as our
guest Joanna Laapore Joanna was an
established and grew foresight at a
couple of organizations you may have
heard of McDonald's and Mars Wrigley and
she's also the founder of foresight
inside group a global group of foresight
and long-term strategic leaders inside
large organizations as well as host of
the looking outside podcast and many
many other exciting work and projects
Joanna welcome to the futurist
Thank you so much for having me on Ross
and congrats on the guest hosting gig
It's fun It's good to be good to be on
the other side of of
of being interviewed to interview
Yeah Yeah I'm feeling I'm feeling that
too being on the other side at the
moment Um it's a nice as a frequent uh
as a frequent podcaster you do all the
interviewing Yeah Pressure is on you now
So I want to hear your story So you have
ended up in these extraordinary roles of
you know running foresight for
McDonald's and all sorts of wonderful
things and uh you just you started small
no doubt to grow to something big So
what's been your how did you find this
was your path
really accidentally as I like to tell
people So I didn't know that you could
be a futurist I didn't realize that that
was a full-time gig that you could have
especially at a big company and for a
big brand I was a marketer for about 10
years out of the Australian market or
kind of Australia AP pack regions Um and
was always really interested in creating
innovation So products services that
helped my organizations usually you know
uh big consumer brands or generally food
brands to look at uh where the growth
was coming in the future so that we
could invest in those areas And because
of that if you think about it kind of
naturally feeds into foresight because
foresight is all about you know
investigating the changes in the world
and helping to um give your stakeholder
a line of sight of how that might be a
competitive advantage for you So it kind
of naturally feeds into marketing
strategy innovation all of those
businessy functions that I did day in
day out But I guess uh at one point I
kind of switched over much more heavily
and intensively into innovation roles
where I was looking at whites space
territories and really looking at
emerging trends and innovations And
because of that I got my first kind of
taste of foresight and then basically
caught the bug And as you said really
extraordinary opportunity to be able to
then go and move to the US and live in
New Jersey and head up and um establish
and grow the foresight function and
capability for Mars Wrigley and then to
be able to move then to Chicago to do
the same thing for McDonald's So being
kind of in those uh global headquarters
and trying to create this very new thing
So like new processes but also new
mindsets and a cultural shift towards
thinking about the long-term future
Absolutely amazing uh opportunities and
um I caught the bug and now now I'm in
it I'm uh like yeah you've sworn me in
I'm dedicated to foresight now Can't get
me out That's awesome It's nice It's
always nice to find your journey and
path in life uh hopefully earlier rather
than later So I mean part of the part of
the thing is as you say you're working
in marketing and and one of the things I
always observe is that uh in marketing
they always bring in these trend
analysts So you get a marketing offsite
or marketing things and they bring in
your trend people but uh of course
trends are not necessarily uh pointing
to the future So there's kind of there
is this cultural shift of how do you
take marketing from say oh here's the
latest trend let's hop on that to
extending that into meaningful thinking
about you know the longer term future
Yeah definitely And you know I think
marketing generally has a little bit of
a preoccupation on one part of foresight
which is cultural analysis Yeah Which is
important which is a part of what we do
But this kind of investigating how
consumer behavior is changing and how
cultural norms are shifting There's and
you know I guess you could say also you
know where we should be speaking to
consumers So the changing media
landscape that's generally kind of the
preoccupation of marketers and so
they're always kind of like feeling like
they're a bit behind on that So help
help me to make sure that I know how
consumer behaviors are shifting so that
I can adapt my strategy Hence they go to
a lot of these generally ad agencies or
cultural analysts to help them to stay
on top of that But I think to to the
point that you made what's really
critical is that you're looking at all
of the other factors that influence the
broader environment that a marketer
operates in or a great business leader
and you know marketers more and more are
asked to be not just a CMO but to be a
real um you know strategist a financial
analyst uh you know a person that can
really wear multiple hats They talk
about a market and are now becoming like
the Ta you know working horizontally
across different functions which
basically means that you need to be
thinking like a futurist You need to
think about macroeconomic conditions You
need to think about geopolitics and
security risks You need to think about
the environment and how your
sustainability teams are looking at
risks and opportunities So I think
that's a really beautiful thing about
foresight and using marketing as kind of
a stepping stone to understand the
changes in the world Starting by deeply
understanding human beings and consumer
behavior but then pushing yourself to to
see more to look for more of those
changes in those kind of broader um you
know macro forces that we as futurists
look at every day Yeah Yeah Yeah And I
think I want to come back a little bit
to I suppose the role of the foresight
person in the organization to shape
leaders in the organization so that they
can become more uh adopt that mindset
and I think that's part of the the the
foresight function is not just to go off
and do your foresight but to uh help the
organization to be more future focused
So you're you're spot on So much of it
is teaching Yes Well let's come back to
that because I want to want to dig into
it But you have spoken and I suppose in
various guises around this idea of you
know foresight as a profession and so uh
as uh as you've observed and I've
observed there's uh you know I've I've
been doing professional futures work for
well certainly over two decades now and
uh I've seen in the last while there's
quite a lot of people putting their
hands up saying I'm a futurist
So uh and you know two sides of that one
is it's fabulous that there's interest
in thinking usefully about the future Um
there's also it can impact the
perception of the field when everyone's
putting their hands up and sort of they
have to distinguish between those who
have uh perhaps a
deeper professional approach to
foresight as opposed to just spouting
off So so where do you think we're at is
in terms of foresight as a profession
yeah I mean I think it's a very fair
observation and particularly for those
of us in the foresight space we feel
this and I say like we feel this like
it's an emotional reaction that a lot of
futurists have to this because people
can call themselves a futurist without
any kind of accreditation And I think
that actually it's okay if we're
welcoming people into the field and
saying you know what you might not you
might not know exactly what you're doing
at first And that's okay Like we want
people to come in from different
disciplines and with different
backgrounds and different ideas
Obviously a great kind of diversity of
thinking comes into foresight That's
really important And not everyone can
can can kind of come in fully qualified
because you might be in a part of the
world where you don't even know what
foresight is or you don't have that
qualification opportunity What I think
is really critical though is that you're
you want to learn to be a better
foresight practitioner that you are
constantly kind of seeking out
information learning more methods
speaking with other people who have been
doing this for two decades like yourself
you know really trying to better
yourself and that you
have at least an ambition to go and get
some qualifications or some qualifi uh
accredititations in the foresight field
so that you understand future studies
You understand how particularly for a
foresight practitioner in a business
setting how it started with Shell and
how it's evolved to where it is now that
you you know um why it started the way
that it is and that you have a
perspective about how to apply it in
your business And you can only really do
that by understanding the methodology
the field Um and like sure what I think
is really great is that you can have
these people who have an entrepreneurial
mindset or kind of the heart and soul of
a futurist Um and you know like
generally these are people who are very
naturally curious very observant
visionary You know they have a view of
how the future should look We really
want those people to come into the
foresight field But calling yourself a
futurist without really understanding
the methods of foresight I think is is
an issue and is a really like easily
solvable problem to have right and I
think that what's what's really great is
that we are starting to see this growth
of particularly in the corporate space
foresight teams or practitioners and the
ability for them to get proper training
in foresight is really easy and there
are so many more institutions that are
offering this you can get access to
materials online really quickly easily
and without a cost So you can educate
yourself you can get education you can
make yourself essentially better at what
you do What futurist wouldn't want to do
that indeed it is Well it's a path of
growth you know It's a path of growth in
expanding ourselves to think more
broadly and uh you know learn how how to
best do that Are there any particular
courses accredititation certificates
whatever that you'd uh point to as
people ones ones aspiring futurists
should look at
yeah So I mean I so I first got mine um
at the Institute for the Future That was
kind of my first official foray and then
in with the Copenhagen Institute for
Future Studies And full disclaimer I
highly recommend them But I'm also now
going to become a partner with the
Copenhagen Institute as of May and we're
going to be looking at how do we build
more uh corporate specific foresight
training into what they do which is
really exciting Um but that being said
you know when I first started in
foresight and I hadn't had the training
yet and I was kind of thinking oh I know
what I'm doing Like I know how to do
trend analysis I've been looking at
trends my whole career I don't need this
like formal certificate What I ended up
doing was actually just speaking with
futurists So speaking with people like
Andy Hines Amy Webb um Paul Safo and
these people are always like super
generous surprisingly super generous
with their time yourself included Ross
when I asked you to for a phone call And
I just feel like you can learn so much
from these conversations Like actually
just having a one-on-one with people who
have been doing this for a while that
have you know maybe a perspective of
what tools and methods might be useful
for the specific problem that you're
trying to solve So even just doing that
I mean it kind of goes back to the point
we were saying before that it really
just requires you to want to learn and
want to grow and be better at doing the
work that we do
So uh so so you mentioned uh well you
mentioned shell which essentially is
obviously been found on scenario
planning Yes Uh so well scenarios or
anything else Are there any particular
methodologies that you have found useful
that you've uh gained insights from that
uh you know part of your toolbox as you
approach foresight issues yeah Yeah
definitely And I know Jerome Glenn's
been a guest on this podcast as well and
I haven't checked that episode out yet
but I will And obviously he's the the
creator of the Futures Wheel method
That's a a really um like a constant
go-to for me for anything that I'm doing
is really looking at the second third
fourth order implications of things And
then what I love is kind of clashing
methods as well So if you clash futures
will with a scenario planning exercise
for example Um the the one that I
normally go to and that I used quite
extensively at the companies that I
worked at was backcasting And
backcasting kind of as a concept or as a
method is a fairly kind of well-known
idea that people can grasp quite quickly
So if you don't need to take them
through like what is a scenario planning
exercise what is a futures wheel
assessment you know you can say "Hey
we're going to go to 2050 and come
backwards to today." It's pretty pretty
easy Um the reason that I love it is
that I think what's really missing
inside of corporations and that kind of
business world when it comes to futures
readiness or foresight is a vision of
the future I know it's also been touched
on this show before as well but you know
this idea that business leaders are
feeling so overwhelmed with everything
that's going on in the world right now
and so much complexity and how do I make
the right decision and you know there's
constantly disruptions and surprises You
know all of that is true but you still
need to know where you're going based on
where you think you have a right to play
and where you think that you can make a
contribution to the world with your
company and your product and the people
that work for you So creating a vision I
think is absolutely integral as a
starting point and that's what
backcasting really does so well It
really takes you to that future makes it
real makes it kind of immersive and
tangible and then you know helps you to
say well me in that future what can I do
what can I influence and then okay let's
create some action plans off the back of
that So I found that to be incredibly
impactful We did like 60 sessions of
back casting um at McDonald's and the
leaders absolutely loved it Everybody
took to it really um really quickly even
if they were like a little bit hesitant
to start Um so that's definitely
probably my favorite Yeah Well one of
the strengths of backing is obviously
the experiential part of it Sort of not
necessarily necessarily describing it
but bringing it to life to the fullest
degree possible There's been some
wonderful work in experiential futures
at uh University of Hawaii and amongst
others But the um and part of it as you
say is this for for me I I'm uh I always
have this positive frame and as in
saying well we we can create the future
you know we are creating the future
everything we do you know particularly
if you're organizational leaders and so
for in order to carve a positive path we
have to have a vision for what is
possible and so you know of course I you
know we need to be very careful about
having you there the very positive and
the very negative you
futures or which is kind of you know
doesn't take you where you want to go
but you can for example say well here
are aspects of this future which I can
see I can experience and I like that and
I can sort of work out how we might have
got to there from here or these are the
things which we can do along the way
which can take us away from that but I
mean the vision is critical in
a you know extraordinary you know
uncertain
accelerating world unless we have vision
around what it is we want to move
towards where you know the old classic
line
you got to know where you want to go in
order to to get there Yeah Exactly And
you know what's really beautiful about
this in the corporate context is that um
business leaders in in the business
landscape are already creating vision
plans I mean that's a strategy You have
a strategy for every department You have
one for the company It's a very natural
thing for business leaders to have to go
and do but generally they do that once
they kind of know where they want to go
Like they already know that they want to
foray into like this growth area So
we're going to create a strategy around
that And so what foresight allows you to
do is then like everything that you just
said is what about all the things we
don't know all the uncertainties in the
world How do you know where you're going
to go if you're not kind of exploring
all of that and sitting in that
uncertainty as well which is like a
little bit less common for a business
leader and obviously less comfortable
but can be so beneficial particularly if
you know they are feeling all of that
kind of anxiety about the growing
complexities of the world Yeah Well also
well most significant organizations have
a vision statement I mean there's a
difference between a bunch of words and
and vision in the sense of I see it you
know and that's that's where you can you
know bring something which is powerful
and say all right well okay I see it and
now I want to create and I've got an
idea of how we might get there Yeah and
and powerful is a nice word to use as
well because I think sometimes when you
do read those vision statements they're
a little like boring and predictable and
again when you do it through for a
foresight lens and really take them into
like a slightly further out future than
what they're familiar with it can push
them to think in a slightly more
creative and imaginative way and so I
guess like the challenge to that is that
sometimes business leaders feel like
that's a waste of time like
theoretically before you take them
through it they're like well we don't
have like the capacity for that or like
what are we going to do with this you
know it feels like a frivolous exercise
because creativity imagination curiosity
all of those things a business knows
they're important but not necessarily
resourcing for them right now in the
midst of all of the other priorities
that they have But when you can
demonstrate to them how that can be
really valuable in you know navigating
all of the complexities of the world and
everything everything else that we just
talked about um yeah it can be like a
very unique exercise for business
leaders and I mean that's I think part
of the reason why there's such a strong
case for foresight or design fiction or
like risk mitigation crisis management
like all of these teams that are now
growing in resourcing in different
organizations because they're doing
things that are familiar for a business
but doing them slightly differently and
really again I think it's still a huge
competitive advantage You mentioned
design fiction Uh any particular
experiences to share on that
yeah So I mean I was actually really
lucky enough to have a few conversations
with Julian Bleecker um and actually
like Paul Sappo and Scott Smith um right
when I was doing this massive exercise
with our leadership team at McDonald's
um because I wanted to implement design
thinking or design fiction or like some
element of this in an exercise with our
leadership team And what I ended up
doing was kind of like a I don't know
like a slight play on a design slash
scenarios exercise where we just tried
to create stories with the scenarios
that we were playing with to make them
like uh tangible So we actually created
something that you could touch and feel
and um you know asking them to uh play
archetypes inside of these stories that
take on the role of one of these people
in the future and you know craft um yeah
craft a narrative around these things
And again it's um it's particularly for
very senior leaders it's not really
something that they're asked to do
dayto-day And so like as a foresight
practitioner you might feel a little bit
nervous even asking for the time to be
able to do something like that But man
you can imagine how some a session like
that or or an exercise like that can
stand out amidst everything else that a
business leader is doing I mean if you
think about it your CEOs your MDs like
they're generally like super busy
reading a ton of things in the earnings
reports you know in the data generally
Um you know they don't have generally
the the space and the permission to be
able to do something like that So it can
really open up their minds And I mean
that's that's the whole point right is
something like design fiction or um
something more creative and imaginative
like speculative fiction inside of a
scenario planning exercise in a business
context That's really what it's designed
to do It's designed to get them to think
about the possibilities and again like
business context Possibilities lead you
to innovation which leads you to growth
So it's in aid of all of these things
that business leaders need and again a
different pathway to get to that Yeah
And I I I love what you said about
opening minds and that that's for me is
exactly what foresight is about Anybody
who is good at that their role is to
basically make leaders think about more
things than they would have in the past
to have that breadth of scope to you
know enrich their thinking and we can
all have richer thinking can all sort of
uh you know encompass more and that's
when you can start to have some you know
the ability to make you know effective
decisions in you know extraordinarily
uncertain times So and you know as you
say you know the fictions or the
narratives or so on they sort of sounds
like all right this is not a what's the
ROI on this but in fact it could
actually be pretty pretty big Yeah Yeah
definitely You know and more more
imaginative decisions as well I mean
what I always say is foresight helps you
to make smarter decisions about the
future in a faster way So you're more
effective and you're more efficient
about decision-m um because you have a
broader consideration set and you can
solve problems in different ways But it
also you know leverages your human skill
in imagination Like you know I know
you've spoken about this as well We are
naturally wired to think about
possibilities and to think about whatifs
from a like sure from a survival
perspective but also like our brains and
our hearts are trained to be open to
possibilities Like we're curious by
nature We are um entranced by novelty
Like we we design things just because we
can because we want to know what it
could possibly lead to I mean like if
you can tap into that from a business
perspective Wow Huge opportunities Yeah
Yeah that's one of the things I love
about humans They're very curious and
that's how we discover things So there
is a part here where there's lots of um
foresight reports you know inside
organizations more broadly saying okay
well this is the whatever name your date
in the future Uh and there is a
sometimes or perhaps more often than
there should be a gap between saying
okay well here's our wonderful foresight
report or analysis or project What does
this mean for our strategy so how how do
we bridge that moving from the foresight
projects and work and reports and
insights through to how this shapes and
improves the strategy of the
organization
Yeah I mean I think that this is the
most critical part and to be an
effective foresight practitioner um you
know whether you're offering a
recommendation externally to your client
or whether you're inside of the
organization you have to be able to pose
a recommendation and that recommendation
needs to be really clearly aligned with
where the business needs to go So like
even before you're doing some sort of an
impact assessment or probability
assessment of how this might impact your
your um your client and your internal
stakeholder you know you really have to
understand what are they trying to
achieve inside of this project and how
can I help them to do that like
generally people have a question that
they're trying to answer So help them
answer that question right um so I think
this is part of the challenge for
foresight is that going back to what we
were saying our job is to open minds and
hearts and get people to think about
possibilities Like yes open up but also
we have to kind of go narrow in and and
not necessarily to say this is
definitely going to happen or make
predictions but certainly to make
recommendations of different pathways
that the business could take because
ultimately that's what a business needs
to do It needs to make decisions So I
think yes um giving a really clear
recommendation that's aligned to the
business challenge is critical and then
the second thing is you know really
creating a roadmap for the business of
how to get there because sometimes you
might actually come out with a pretty
obvious recommendation like the business
already kind of was like should we
should we not yes you should okay cool
we kind of felt that way already but
they don't really know how to do that
like an example is you know if you're
getting an an organization to you know
um in Mars for example we were making
chocolate and we were saying well is
plant-based chocolate a thing like is
dairyfree chocolate you know something
that we should be investing in we're
going to have to get new capital We're
going to have to educate consumers It's
going to cost us more money etc So it's
the how we do it that's sometimes the
bigger question than the should we do it
And so I think that's also where a
foresight practitioner should come in
and not necessarily do that all by
themselves but a road map a pathway
sometimes even a commercial business
case partnering with the team that's
really working on that to create kind of
like a how you could do this is really
critical and I think that's why you know
if you look at a foresight practitioner
they've got the evidence of the future
all around them they've got the signals
of how other companies and brands are
doing it you know sometimes someone
that's living and breathing this problem
in the business they're kind of looking
at it from one lens like how my
immediate competitor would solve this
problem or you know how I could do this
in the most costefficient or costneutral
way whereas a foresight person is always
looking outside in so we're seeing how
you could solve that problem in new and
unique ways or you know potentially even
seeing new innovations or new startups
that might be able to partner with you
to do this in a different way so that's
where I think the partnership really
needs to come into play is foresight
actually still being a part of that
process end to end So not just being at
that front end and saying here's all the
cool things that are trending off you go
Um our job is done but to really stay
with that stakeholder all the way
through the process from recommendation
through to the road map of how you could
get there And then hopefully if you have
a great foresight practitioner they're
there even afterwards right like they're
they're um they're checking their
assumptions they're coming in and saying
"Okay you had to make some some
compromises over here This is what it
could mean for you right against you're
still doing implications You're still
doing scenarios just in a different
way." Um but I think that's where
foresight is most effective inside of a
business is where it's a partner
throughout the entire process Yep And I
think you know one example of that could
be starting with the future of the
consumer and then you come up with come
up with some ideas and then you got to
do the future of the supply chain on how
do we deliver on that Yeah Yeah Exactly
Exactly And you know that's um there's
so much growth in that as well in supply
chain teams sustainability teams risk
management teams like everybody wants a
piece of foresight which is a great
problem to have So drum roll We're on to
our lightning round So snappy answers
Let's hear what you've got to say So
okay So Joe what was the first science
fiction you remember stimulating your
mind
terminator 2 Uh and I know you said
lightning round quick answers but I'll
tell you this was like a really easy
answer for me because I was in Poland
right so this is like when we just
started getting movies from America
which was a big deal And I was 8 years
old and I was like sitting um sitting
away from the TV covering my ears and
closing my eyes because I was so
petrified by the Terminator So you know
maybe that's part of the reason why I
have a fear of AI Hopefully hopefully I
haven't scarred you for life All right
So what technology has most influenced
humanity
um so I'm not going to say most
influenced I'm going to cheat on this
one I'm going to say the one that I
think is understated in its impact um
because obviously it's not the biggest
but I think it's had massive
implications and it's plastic and
specifically plastic's invention in uh
the the start of the last century and
how it's been applied to everything and
how it's impacted the food industry I've
got to say I still I still go back to
that line in um you know the Simon G the
Simon what's the the movie with Simon
and Guncle Paul Simon in it or they had
the song
um oh it's a classic forgotten the name
of the movie anyway the line was you
know the the future one one word you
need to know for the future plastics and
that was in the 60s yeah well that's
accurate it's an accurate prediction
Uh so name a futurist or other person
who has shaped the way you think about
the world
Um I am going to say
uh this this was a really hard one for
me
Um and it like constantly changes I'm
sorry I'm terrible at this uh lightning
round Um I'm going to say Amy Webb uh
from a foresight perspective Um she was
the first futurist that I thought "Oh
cool I can use the foresight methods
that I already know and apply for like
futurism to them." Excellent So so
what's uh what's your favorite
prediction ever made
i'm going to go with Carl Sean and his
1985 speech to US Congress about the
environment and how we were all screwed
Yes I think that was brilliant
Uh so hopefully not too precient Uh and
so which science fiction is most
representative of the future you hope
for definitely Star Trek Next Generation
Um and particularly because it's so
altruistic and positive and sci-fi is
not not normally very positive Although
I was reflecting on this and I was
thinking you know what's really
interesting about Star Trek is that
there's not a lot of personalization in
it Like if we were writing Star Trek
today Jeanluke Picard would come in and
the AI would already know that he wants
his Earl Grey tea hot but and yet he has
to order it every time So maybe we were
kind of like underestimating how much
personalization would come into the
future Yes So I I love going back to the
